  in educational research

<div id="csl-bib-meta-FHHA2T7Y" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-FHHA2T7Y" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Stalheim conducted a case study on architectural students participating in a voluntary workshop called 'Speed Practice.' The study explored the students' engagement and experiences, highlighting the importance of being open to unexpected insights during research. Stalheim discussed the challenges of defining a study design and constructing research questions, noting the biases researchers may bring. By participating in the workshop, Stalheim gained a deeper understanding of the students' perspectives. This approach advocates for increased student involvement and alternative methods to understand teaching and learning in higher education. The findings emphasize the value of student stories in shaping educational research and practices.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-FHHA2T7Y" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Revolting Spirit, Architectural Students, Voluntary Workshop, Methodological Challenges, Student Engagement, Higher Education
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-FHHA2T7Y" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    This case study report delves into the search for the revolting spirit among architectural students 
participating in a voluntary workshop called 'Speed Practice'. It focuses on the methodological 
challenges and considerations encountered during the research process, shedding light on the 
importance of embracing openness to unexpected insights. 
In the report, I discuss the process of defining a study design, allowing the students' stories and 
experiences to unfold naturally and illuminate how the research sought to gain a deeper 
understanding of their engagement. 
Further, I emphasize the complexities of constructing research questions and the inherent biases 
researchers bring to their investigations. By immersing myself as a participant in the workshop, 
I gained a firsthand perspective, deepening my understanding of the students' viewpoints. This 
approach contributes to exploring student experiences in higher education, advocating for 
increased student involvement and alternative ways to understand teaching and learning.
  </article>
